page.lettertext:
fol.239r
Belgia
Belgia: 1590: July.
29 July 1590
Maye it please yo
r
good Lordshipe by our Laste of the
22 of this presente wee sygnefyed howe farre wee
had
ceeded w
th
the
Stat
generall
uppon the
Pointe of Instructiones
pounded unto them ime-
diatelye after the dispache of w
ch
letters we pre-
ssed againe some bettere Resolutyo
n
to our first
-
posytyones whearunto they Answered that unlese
wee wold declare in writynge the Reasones of our
myslyke of their Aunsweres and ower objectyones to
their Appostelles they myght not well
ceede to any
further Consultac
on
, havinge alredy delyvered as
muche as myghte be yelded unto consyderinge
the presente state of their Contrey and affaires
hearuppo
n
to avoide Lose of tyme we presently
framed some objectyones in writynge to the moste
materialle poynt
of their Appostelles w
ch
wee
delyvered in their Assembly inlarginge the same
by speeches as wee thoughte Convenyent for ther
bettere inducemente to allowe of our demaund
and w
th
all did exibit the Reste of the matteres
wee had to
pound all at once to the ende we
myghte Receave some speedye Answeare to the
whole./.
The 24th wee receaved from them an acte sent
unto us by
Arlens
their Secretarye signefieng
their intensyo
n
to send or Reporte to their provinces
as well o
r
objectyones as our second proposytyons
and therfor desyred of us yf wee had any othere
thinge incharge that myght Require their Ans-
weare wee wold vouchesafe to delyvere it all-
together to be imparted w
th
the Reste to their Su-
periores whos mynd
and Resolutyones they pur-
posed to have uppo
n
the whole matteres of our
Negotyac
on
./.
Wee marvelynge greatly at this determenac
on
of the stat
to send agayne to their provinces and
thearby to detracte the tyme havinge by their acte
declared a suffitiencye of Authoretye in themse-
lves to treate and Conclud w
th
us uppo
n
the
matteres of our Charge, wee Resorted unto them
and delyvered our opynyones howe Needlese it
was for them to take that Course in Respect that
by the
fol.239v
Belgia: 1590: July
by the xix
th
Artycle of the treatye thear was all
redy graunted unto
the
hir Ma
tie
and to the
Cou-
nselle of the Estate
full powre and Authoretye
for the Estableshinge of all thing
that did Conce-
rve the goode of the Comone wealle or maters
of their Martyall diseplyne and that our seco-
nde proposytyone tended in effecte to an Expl-
anac
on
of that artycle, This Artycle wee did
purposly from the beginninge forbeare to urge, su-
pposyng that they of them selves in their answers
unto us wold alwayes have had Consyderac
on
thearof, but suche was ether their oversighte
in Not Considering the substance of the Artycle
or their Skylle and Connynge advisedly to omite
the same as when they
ceaved us Resolutlye
to presse the observance of that Artycle they Rise
from the table in a soarte amazed and Retired
them selves into another Rome to advise uppo
n
their Answere, whear aftere they had Conferred
more then a quartere of an howere they Returned
and by their preseydente
John Vander Wark
one
of the deputed for
Zeland
they delyvered that for
asmuche as hir Ma
tie
had Refused the soverainty
of their Provinces beinge offered unto hir they su-
pposed she wold not nowe seeke it by vertue of
the Contracte, that to have more head
or So-
veraignes in their stat then one was to make
the same a monstere, that the Authoretye gra-
unted to hir Ma
tie
by this Artycle was to be Ex-
ercysed but for one tyme onelye w
ch
was allr-
edy Executed by the Comynge of the
Earle of
Leastere
as hir Ma
t
generall into thes Contr-
eyes and that thearfore the effecte of that arty-
cle was already
formed and the Artycle va-
nished wee disproved their Concepte of any pur-
pos of any demaund of soverainety in hir Ma
tie
by Requiringe the Authoretye yelded by that Ar-
ticle and declared that the same was not gr-
aunted to hir Ma
tie
allone but to hir and the Co-
unsell of Estate Joyntly who weare all theire
Compatriot
and of their owne body selected &
Chosen by the severall provinces as
sones to
who
m
the
fol.240r
Belgia: 1590: July.
who
m
the excersyes of their soverainty was Co-
mytted and suche as in all formore tymes w
th
e
governores of their provinces evere injoyed the
lyke under their Princes wee lykewise disproved
their Constructyo
n
made of the artycle by Com-
paring the sent theareof w
th
the whole bodye of
the treatye and made it appeare unto them that
the same was No more extract then the Rest
t
Contynued in beinge and so
cecuted the Con-
firmac
on
therof by asmany argument
as we
Could in thend after longe debatynge and No
alterac
on
of their Concepte and opynyone touc-
hinge their Explycac
on
of the artycle appering
wee weare forced thoughe in temperate ma-
nners) some Round speeches unto them signe-
fyeng howe sorye wee weare to discovere their
backward affectyones to hir Ma
tie
so clearly ma-
nifested by this Conferrence/ The protested
Neveretheles their greate devotyo
n
to hir Ma
tie
and fynally prayed that what they had sayd
to the purpos of the Artycle myght not be
takene as an Aunswere but that they wolde
imparte our allegacones to their provinces &
Receave our answere and resolutyo
n
to the said
Article, wee suspectynge what the provinces
myght resolve uppo
n
their Constructyo
n
to be
made of the force of the article answered that
yf they mente to p
n
t the mattere in delybera-
cone amonge their provinces wee wold in-
lyke soarte recomende the same to the inter-
pretac
on
of yo
r
Lordshipes and the Reste that-
weare in Comissyone from hir Ma
tie
in Con-
cluding the
tretye
treaty whearof it maye
please yo
r
Lordshipes to have good Considerac
on
and (yf it maye so seeme good unto yo
u
) that the
opynyone of the beste learned in the Civille
Lawes in
England
maye be takene uppo
n
the
Substance of the Article and signefyed hether
w
th
yo
r
Lordshipes Constructyo
n
of the same,
t
they maye not evad from us in this pointe
e
the Rather
fol.240v
Belgia: 1590: July.
the Rather for that wee
ceave wee shall hardlye
establishe anye suffityent authoretie in the Governor
and Counselle of Estate heare yf wee yelde to the
anulling of that article beinge Certenly enformed
t
some of this assembly have alredye before hande gev-
ene Caviat
to their provinces to beware howe they
accord to their governore and Counsell of Estate
the powre gevene by the Contracte because they
shalle ther in yeld them Royalle authoretye w
ch
by
the
Stat
Generalle
is Challenged by tradissy
o
frome the people to Remayne in them and Cane
by No meanes Indure that a governor from
hir Ma
tie
w
th
the Counsell should be invested w
th
that authoretye. by their Reces (as they terme
it) to their Province theare wilbe muche delaye
used and is in our Conceipt
done of purpos to win
tyme that they maye see what succes maye hap-
ppene in
Fraunce
yf the
kinge
become possessed
of
Paris
accordinge whearunto they will streygh-
tene or inlarge themselves in allowinge the dem-
aund
made by hir Ma
tie
not that they will ha-
stelye become frenche but that they shall therby
discerne howe the enemy maye be imployed and
hindred from any Notable attempte againste them
and so mesure their owne Necessetye to be Relee-
ved by hir Ma
tie
./.
The Resolutiones that shalle nowe be draune fr
o
the
vinces to the matteres wee have propounded
will yeld the Answeres thearunto of the States
so absolute as our further replyes or objectyones
will Nothinge altere the same or prevayle
or pr-
evaile a
to amend or reforme the same any jott
of their determynac
on
havinge alredye at great
lengthe at many meetynges delyvered asmuche
and as many Reasons on hir Ma
t
parte as in
our poore opynyones of theis Contreyes &
matteres wee have delyvered and thearfor nowe
after wee shall have Conferred w
th
the Counsell
of State to who
m
wee meane to Repaire to
Ar-
nhem
(I Thomas Wilk
shall have Nothinge to
doe heare but to attend the Aunswer from the
Provinces
fol.241r
Belgia: 1590: July
Provinces and States w
ch
I looke to Receave the
ende of Septembere nexte and not before, in
e
meanetyme for seeinge the Event hearof I mo-
tioned unto the States as of my selfe that they
wold lyke of any Repaire into England pretend-
inge some
tyculer Cause of myne owne and
to Returne hether at suche tyme as I myghte
understand from them of their Resolutyones taken
in the Poynt
of my Negotyatione whearunto
they wold in no soarte Condicende but intrea-
ted me to staye for that they desired to growe
to some Conclusyo
n
uppo
n
the Condissyones I
had delyvered Concernyng their trade to Sp-
aine, our purpos of Conference w
th
the Counsell
is to move them to Joyne w
th
us in Clayminge
e
authoretye graunted by the Contracte and because
I Thomas Bodley by the knoledge I have of their
disposytyones doe thinke they will be hardly indu-
ced to Concurre w
th
us publykely in that behalfe
by Reasone they are for the moste parte unw-
illinge to offend the Stat
as fearinge to be Re-
moved from their places or otherwise disgrac-
ed wee intend to urge them uppo
n
their othe
takene for the observac
on
of the Contract and ther
in Nevere the Lese to be advised and to use suche
Course and discressyo
n
as maye beste furder the
Cause and leaste offend theone or the other.
Untylle it maye be seene what shalbe Resolv-
ede and aunswered to our propossytyone thus-
fare for the mattere of our Instructyone wher-
in wee doe proteste unto yo
r
Lordshipes uppo
n
our alleagence to the Queenes ma
tie
wee have
Traveled and endevored all that we maye not
onely in our publycke Confferences w
th
the stat
in generall but withe the Cheefeste of them in
ticulere and Cannote for oure Lyves forejudge
what successe will followe of our actyones
hearin suche and so strange hathe byne the ma-
nnere of their
ceeding
w
th
us, usyng bothe Ro-
ughe and myld Comunycac
on
w
th
them, thou-
ghe w
th
out affecte./.
Wee Receaved from the Leifetenante governore
of the
Brille
a lettere dated the .25. of this pres-
presente
fol.241v
Belgia. 1590: July.
presente advertesynge that the victuelere having
brought Corne to the towne for the provissyo
n
of
the Garrysone wheare the orderes are nowe to
be put in Executyone the Burgeres of the Towne
have inhibeted that Nether the mylleres shall gr-
inde the Corne Nor the bakeres Bake the same
Whearby theare appearethe a Resolutyo
n
in the
people to oppose them selves against that parte
of the orderes for victuellinge of the souldiere, and
by cause for some Reasones alledged in our form-
ore letteres wee thinke it not fyt e at this tyme
to make any Garboyle between the towne and
the Garrisone wee have thought good to advise
the Leiutenante Governore to forbeare the Ex-
ecusyo
n
of the orderes in that pointe untylle
yo
r
Lordshipes myght be Advertysed of this oppo-
sityone (W
ch
wee Conceave to growe underhand
from the States) that wee might Receave yo
r
Aunsweare and directyone hearin/ And trulye
my Lo: wee fynde bothe by the Stat
and by
e
townes (Who sithence wee begane to treate) here
have sente unto us their Burghures and prin-
cepalle offyceres to praye that the victualynge
myght be forborne) that it is so offensyve to the
inhabytance of the townes as it will breed a
greate allyanac
on
of the people from hir Ma
tie
for the Apparrells of the Souldieres the Stat
and townes doe not muche myslyke, and to the
Souldiere himselfe theare is nothing more offe-
ncyve then the victuelle w
ch
(as they Complayn
in all the garysones) is not onely very Corrupt
but sold unto thend at higher Rat
then is affo-
rded by the Townes and what furder inconv-
eniences doe growe thearof will beste appeare
unto yo
r
Lorshipes by the Artycles Lately sente
unto yo
u
from the Governore and Captaynes of
Bergene
whearwithe we have byne made
acquinted and fynd them all worthie of Consy-
derac
on
w
ch
wee moste hombly Refer to yo
r
good
Lorshipes and to take our Leave from the Hage
the 29
th
of July
1590
